Class ec.e.inspect.Inspector 
All Packages  Class Hierarchy  This Package  Previous  Next  Index

Class ec.e.inspect.Inspector 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.e.inspect.Inspector
public class Inspector
extends Object
The Inspector class serves two purposes: As a dynamic class, it encapsulates inspectability of a class or an Array. To inspect an object, you create an inspector for it and hand it to an InspectorUI. The InspectorUI reference is kept in a static variable in Inspector. The IFC-based Inspector UI is one possible and useful value for this. As a static class it contains methods to collect and manage global collections of inspectable objects, gathered using the gather() methods, and a collection of already inspected objects to ensure that there is only one instance of inspector and Inspector UI (window) for each object. If gatherEnabled is false, then gathering is disabled. Gathering objects can (potentially) be done before defining an inspector UI.

Inspector 
  protected Inspector(Object object,
                      String objectName)

inspect 
  public static void inspect(Object object,
                             String name)
Immediately inspect an object with a given name, using whatever user interface has been set up. If no user interface is available, then this is a no-op - The rationale is that since this is mostly used for debugging, and there may be many reasons to disable this feature (including user preference and security considerations) the unability to Inspect should never annoy an innocent user. Developers will be savvy enough to figure out why the Inspector does not work - typically noone has called setUI() which typically means noone has created the GUI half of the Inspector (currently typically based on IFC). Note that for the IFC GUI case it may have been created and linked in as a UI but may not appear on the screen until it has been asked to inspect something.
Parameters:
object, - nullOK, suspect - The object to be inspected. If the object is null, then this call has no effect besides (if not done before) initializing the Inspector's UI and thereby possibly forcing an inspector control panel window to appear in the case of a Graphical UI such as IFC.
name - nullOK, suspect - A string to use as the name of the object. If the name is null, we use the name "Object". If the name is already used for a different object, then we will add a uniquefying integer to the name.
enableGathering 
  public static void enableGathering(boolean enabled)
Enable or disable gathering of objects
gather 
  public static void gather(Object iobj,
                            String category,
                            String name)
gather - collect an object for possible later inspection.
Parameters:
object, - nullOK, suspect - The object to be gathered. You can only mark any object for inspection once so if it is already been marked in another category or by another name then another marking will be ignored. Not always what you want, but allowing duplicates would use lots of hashtable entries if you attempted to mark an object for inspection when in a loop. Also, please note that any objects you mark for inspection will never be garbage collected since the inspector holds a reference to it. Therefore there exists a way to delete all entries from the gathering hashtables.
category, - nullOK, suspect - A string category name; like a folder that can be used to organize objects to be inspected. It may be null.
name, - nullOK, suspect - A string to use as the name of the object. If the name is already used in the category given (if any) by another object then we add a unique integer to its name.
gather 
  public static void gather(Object object,
                            String name)
gather - Collect an object that we don't want to classify in any category for possible inspection sometime later.
Parameters:
object, - nullOK, suspect - The object to be gathered. You can only mark any object for inspection once so if it is already been marked in another category or by another name then another marking will be a no-op. Not always what you want. Allowing duplicates would use lots of hashtable entries if you attempted to mark an object for inspection when in a loop. Also, please note that any objects you mark for inspection will never be garbage collected since the inspector holds a reference to it. Therefore there exists a way to delete all entries from the gathering hashtables.
name, - nullOK, suspect - A string to use as the name of the object. If the name is already used in the category given (if any) by another object then we add a unique integer to its name.
dropAllGatheredObjects 
  public static void dropAllGatheredObjects()
Drop all gathered objects. This allows them to be garbage collected and allows us to focus on newly gathered objects
isInspecting 
  public boolean isInspecting(Object object)
Compare our inspected object against another object. Provided for Inspector UI.
Parameters:
object, - nullOk, suspect - Object to compare our inspected object to.
getObjectsWithoutCategory 
  public static Hashtable getObjectsWithoutCategory()
Provided for Inspector UI.

XXX Major capability leak and security hole. Anyone can access all gathered uncategorized objects in the system.

getObjectCategories 
  public static Hashtable getObjectCategories()
Provided for Inspector UI.

XXX Major capability leak and security hole. Anyone can access all gathered categorized objects in the system.

setUI 
  public static void setUI(InspectorUI inspectorUI)
Assign an Inspector UI to the Inspector.

XXX Major capability leak and security hole. Anyone can call this method and thereby gain access to all inspected objects in the system. Ability to set oneself up as an inspector in a running system should be a closely held capability.

createInspectorForObject 
  public static Inspector createInspectorForObject(Object object,
                                                   String name)
Create an inspector for a given object. Provided as a low-level call to be used only from the InspectorUI subsystem.

XXX Major security hole. Anyone can (currently) access internal state by inspecting any object they can reach in the system. Access to this capability should be limited to a debugging situation. Access to object internals should be limited by the openers you possess. Here we use the global root opener and can therefore open anything we have a reference to.

Parameters:
object - suspect - The object to inspect. The object cannot be null.
name - suspect - The name of the object. The name cannot be null.
reCreateInspector 
  public Inspector reCreateInspector()
Create another inspector inspecting the same object but (in future) using a different opener. Note that we need a way to specify which opener to use so this choice will (eventually) be passed in as as an argument.
getMyObjectName 
  public String getMyObjectName()
Return the name of the inspected object itself (the top level name, as opposed to names of specific fields)
isEditable 
  public boolean isEditable(int n)
Return the number of instance variables (visible using our current opener) in the inspected object or array elements if the inspected object is an array. Basically, this number will likely determine the number of "lines" of visible output in the Inspector UI used.
isReference 
  public boolean isReference(int n)
Tells whether a field with a given index is a reference object or not
createInspector 
  public Inspector createInspector(int fieldIndex) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Create an inspector for the data in a field, given the field index.
getAssignedSignature 
  public String getAssignedSignature(int fieldIndex) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Return the signature of the actually assigned data in a field. Note that this may differ from the declared signature in some cases, like if a field is declared a reference to some class of object and it has been assigned an object of some subclass thereof
getNumberFields 
  public abstract int getNumberFields()
Return the number of fields (slots or array elements) in the object or array
getInheritedNumberFields 
  public abstract int[] getInheritedNumberFields()
Return an array of ints listing the number of visible instance variables at each level.
getName 
  public abstract String getName(int fieldIndex) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Return the variable name of a field.
getDeclaredSignature 
  public abstract String getDeclaredSignature(int fieldIndex) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Return the declared signatures for a field
get 
  public abstract Object get(int fieldIndex) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Return the value of a field of the currently inspected Object, given a field index. Returns a reference data type. Primitive data types will be wrapped.
Parameters:
fieldIndex - - The index of the local variable field according to the used opener, or the index of the element if the object being inspected is an array.
Returns:
Object, nullOK, suspect - the object designated by fieldIndex and the used opener. Primitive data types are wrapped into Objects.
set 
  public abstract void set(int fieldIndex,
                           Object newValue) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Set the value of a field, given a field index, and a new value. Only works for newValue arguments that are reference data types - primitive data types should be wrapped.
Parameters:
fieldIndex - - The index of the local variable field according to the used opener, or the index of the element if the object being inspected is an array.
newValue, - nullOK, trusted - The new value to assign to the instance variable. Note that this variable is marked as "trusted" - The inspector itself is not assuming the value to be trusted but since we are adding the reference to another arbitrary inspected object we are in fact relaying the reference and all capabilities it embodies to the receiving object.
